coredata.dc:title: Graphitic carbon nitride stabilized the lithium anode/sulfide electrolyte interface for all-solid-state lithium-sulfur battery
coredata.dc:creator: Zhao, Yao
Lu, Huichao
Kong, Xirui
Yang, Jun
Nuli, Yanna
Wang, Jiulin
coredata.dc:description: Sulfide solid-state electrolytes (SSEs) are expected to fundamentally avoid the polysulfides shuttle and Li dendrites growth in the traditional liquid electrolyte lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries owing to its ultrahigh ionic conductivity, the high mechanical strength and favorable interfacial compatibility with sulfide-based cathodes. However, the sulfide SSEs are thermodynamically unstable to Li metal, and the parasitic reactions between the Li anode and sulfide SSEs results in intolerable interface deterioration. Herein, a graphitic carbon nitride (GCN, g-C3N4)-dominated artificial interlayer was introduced to enhance the interfacial stability between Li metal and sulfide SSEs. The introduction of electrochemically inert GCN is revealed to effectively alleviate the formation of heterogenous resistance layers for long-term. Furthermore, the abundant nitrogen species within GCN layer homogenize the distribution of Li ions flux, which effectively smooths Li deposition and suppresses dendrites growth. Herein, the symmetric cells with the Li-GCN show a stable plating/stripping cycling for over 1100 h at 0.2 mA cm−2 and a capacity of 0.2 mAh cm−2. The all-solid-state Li-SPAN battery with g-C3N4 interphase exhibits a highly reversible capacity of 579 mAh g−1 and a capacity retention of 88% at 0.2C after 150 cycles, as well as achieves an excellent rate performance.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Schematic diagram of the interface evolution of the Li or Li-GCN and Li6PS5Cl (LPSC). (a) The formation of fragile and heterogenous SEI from Li/LSPC interfacial side reaction induces the growth and penetration of Li dendrites. (b) The g-C3N4 layer rich in Li3N alleviates the interface reaction and facilitates the uniform Li stripping/planting at Li-GCN/LPSC interface.

(a) The TEM image of exfoliated GCN nanosheets. (b) Top-view SEM image of Li-GCN and corresponding C and N element distribution. (c) The AFM image of Li-GCN anode. (d) FTIR spectra for GCN. (e) XPS spectra for GCN. (f) XRD patterns of as-prepared GCN, pristine Li metal and Li/GCN mixture. High-resolution XPS analysis of (g) N 1s and (h) C 1s and (i) Li 1s for GCN, Li and Li-GCN surface.

Galvanostatic cycles of Li stripping/plating process of Li-Li symmetric at (a) 0.2 mA cm−2, 0.2 mAh cm−2, (b) 0.1 mA cm−2, 0.5 mAh cm−2 and (c) 0.5 mA cm−2, 0.1 mAh cm−2 at room temperature. EIS plots and corresponding equivalent circuit of (d) Li/LPSC/Li and (e) Li-GCN/LPSC/Li-GCN cells at different cycles.

The SEM image of surface of cycled (a) Li anodes and (b) Li-GCN anode. The SEM image of cross-section of cycled (c) Li/LPSC interface and (d) Li-GCN/LPSC interface. XPS characterization of LPSC obtained from disassembled Li/LPSC/Li and Li-GCN/LPSC/Li-GCN symmetric cells after 100 cycles at 0.2 mA cm−2 (e) S 2p spectra, (f) P 2p spectra. (g) TOF-SIMS cross-section images of Li-GCN surface after cycling corresponding to the depth profiles.

(a) Long-term cycling of all-solid-state Li-SPAN cells at the current density of 0.1C. (b) Rate performance of the Li/LPSC/SPAN cell and Li-GCN/LPSC/SPAN cell at the various current densities from 0.1C to 0.5C. (c) The charge/discharge profiles of Li/LPSC/SPAN cell at 1st, 5th, 20th and 50th. (d) The charge/discharge profiles of Li/LPSC/SPAN cell at 0.1C, 0.2C, 0.3C and 0.5C. (e) Ex-situ EPR spectra SPAN cathode at different discharge and charge states. The EIS plots and corresponding equivalent circuit of (f) Li/LPSC/SPAN cell and (h) Li-GCN/LPSC/SPAN cell at the initial stage and 100 cycles. Resistance values corresponding to EIS equivalent circuit of (g) Li/LPSC/SPAN cell and (i) Li-GCN/LPSC/SPAN cell. All-electrochemical performance of all-solid-state Li-SPAN cells are tested at 50 °C.

Stady on charge–discharge kinetics of SPAN cathode in Li-GCN/LPSC/SPAN cells. (a) GITT curve of second cycle of Li-GCN/LPSC/SPAN cell. (b) Calculated diffusion coefficient at different voltage during discharging and charging. (c) CV curves of Li-GCN/LPSC/SPAN at various scan rates. (d) Fitting curves of the square root of scan rate (v 1/2) and the peak current (ip) of CV. (e) The cycling performance and (f) rate performance with CCCV charging.

head.ce:title: Graphitic carbon nitride stabilized the lithium anode/sulfide electrolyte interface for all-solid-state lithium-sulfur battery

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: Department of Chemical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: State Key Laboratory of Chemistry and Utilization of Carbon-based Energy Resources

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: Sichuan Research Institute of Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Chengdu, 610213, Sichuan, China

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Sulfide solid-state electrolytes (SSEs) are expected to fundamentally avoid the polysulfides shuttle and Li dendrites growth in the traditional liquid electrolyte lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries owing to its ultrahigh ionic conductivity, the high mechanical strength and favorable interfacial compatibility with sulfide-based cathodes. However, the sulfide SSEs are thermodynamically unstable to Li metal, and the parasitic reactions between the Li anode and sulfide SSEs results in intolerable interface deterioration. Herein, a graphitic carbon nitride (GCN, g-C3N4)-dominated artificial interlayer was introduced to enhance the interfacial stability between Li metal and sulfide SSEs. The introduction of electrochemically inert GCN is revealed to effectively alleviate the formation of heterogenous resistance layers for long-term. Furthermore, the abundant nitrogen species within GCN layer homogenize the distribution of Li ions flux, which effectively smooths Li deposition and suppresses dendrites growth. Herein, the symmetric cells with the Li-GCN show a stable plating/stripping cycling for over 1100 h at 0.2 mA cm−2 and a capacity of 0.2 mAh cm−2. The all-solid-state Li-SPAN battery with g-C3N4 interphase exhibits a highly reversible capacity of 579 mAh g−1 and a capacity retention of 88% at 0.2C after 150 cycles, as well as achieves an excellent rate performance.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: No data was used for the research described in the article.

ce:section.ce:para: The limitation of energy density and safety hazard of traditional lithium-ion batteries cannot meet the demands of large-scale energy storage and electric vehicles [1–3], Li-S batteries with ultrahigh energy density of 2600 Wh kg−1 are regarded as the next generation of energy storage systems [4]. However, the dissolution shuttle of polysulfides under the traditional reaction mechanism, the uncontrolled Li dendrites growth and the safety hazards associated with flammable conventional electrolytes seriously hinder the practical application of Li-S batteries [5]. The sulfurized polyacrylonitrile (SPAN) proposed in 2002 achieved a new mechanism of solid–solid transformation in the carbonate-based electrolyte, and the utilization rate of active material was close to 100 % without polysulfide shuttle, showing an amazing cycling performance [6]. Unfortunately, the problem of Li dendrites growth and pulverization is quite serious, which is not conducive to the construction of long cycle life and safe Li-S batteries. The development of solid-state electrolytes (SSEs) provides a feasible solution to the problem existing in Li-S batteries [7,8].

In recent years, sulfide SSEs have attracted the wide attention of researchers due to their superhigh ionic conductivity comparable to that of organic electrolytes (∼10-2 S cm−1), high mechanical strength and similar chemical potential with SPAN cathode [9,10]. Unfortunately, the high mechanical modulus of the SSEs did not inhibit the short circuit caused by Li growth and penetration as expected even at lower current density [11–13]. The Li dendrite growth was easily induced by physical factors such as microstructure, defects and contact loss of SSEs surface. In addition, it has been proved theoretically and experimentally that sulfide SSEs are incompatible with Li metal. The interfacial side reaction caused by the poor thermodynamic compatibility between Li metal and sulfide SSEs results in the formation of heterogeneous resistance interphase, which reduces the tolerance to Li dendrite growth [14]. In situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy measurements by Wenzel et al. showed that the continuous chemical diffusion of Li and the sulfide SSEs led to the formation of an interphase with high resistance, which results in serious deterioration of electrochemical performance [15]. Various strategies have been adopted to optimize the Li/sulfide SSEs interface [16–18]. One of the most effective strategy is to replace Li metal with Lithium-indium (Li-In) alloy, which significantly alleviates the reductive decomposition of sulfide SSEs at low potentials [19], but its higher redox potential (0.62 V vs Li+/Li) makes the discharge platform voltage of all-solid-state Li-S batteries assembled with SPAN cathode only about 1.2 V as well as its larger molecular weight, which great reduces overall energy density of battery. Optimizing the composition of sulfide SSEs by elements doping, such as Si [20], Cl [21], I [22], O [23] is expected to produce high quality interphase after degradation, but this method generally sacrifices the ionic conductivity of SSEs. It is a wise choice to construct an electronic shielding interface modification layer with good compatibility between Li metal and sulfide SSEs to stabilize the interface and inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites [24,25]. One popular strategy is to use flexible polymers, such as polyethylene oxide (PEO) [26], polysiloxane [27], poly (propylene carbonate) (PPC) [28], and polyethylene glycol dimethyl ether (PEGDME) [29] to improve poor solid–solid contact interface and isolate sulfides SSE from Li metal. However, the low Li+ diffusivity of polymer and the poor compatibility between the organic interlayer and sulfide SSEs remains to be considered.

The graphitic carbon nitride (GCN) layer, which has good chemical stability and flexibility, has been shown to alleviate interfacial side reactions and regulate the deposition behavior of Li metal in liquid electrolyte systems, but whether it is still effective in solid electrolyte systems has not been investigated [30,31]. Herein, we propose to construct an artificial solid electrolyte interphase by modifying the Li anode with graphitic carbon nitride nanosheets (Li-GCN) to stabilize the interface (Fig. 1 ). The Li-GCN electrode coated with electrochemically inert GCN layer isolates the direct contact between Li metal and sulfide SSEs, thereby alleviating the decomposition of sulfide SSEs and the formation of resistance interphase dominated by Li2S. Moreover, it is confirmed that Li3N derived from the abundant nitrogen species in Li-GCN surface provided Li+ transport channels and promoted the homogenous Li+ flux distribution in the interphase, ensuring the uniformly Li plating/stripping behavior. Consequently, the Li-GCN electrode based symmetric cells exhibit stable cycling for over 1100 h at a current density of 0.2 mA cm−2. Moreover, the all-solid-state Li-SPAN cell delivers a highly reversible capacity of 579 mAh g−1 and a capacity retention of 88% after 150 cycles at 0.2C. This work verifies the feasibility of introducing an interphase with reduction stability to optimize the Li/sulfide SSEs interface.

g-C3N4 is prepared by thermally induced polycondensation of precursors. Briefly, 10 g melamine was thermally calcined for 4 h at 550 °C with a rate of 5 °C/min, and the resulting yellow aggregates were fully ground with a mortar to obtain g-C3N4 powder.

The prepared g-C3N4 powder was dispersed in tetrahydrofuran solution at a ratio of 2 mg/mL, and then sonicated for 12 h to exfoliate the stacked g-C3N4 blocks into few-layers g-C3N4 nanosheets. After further centrifugation at 4500 rpm/min for 1 h, a pale yellow g-C3N4 nanosheets suspension was obtained. The Li-GCN was obtained by drip-casting the g-C3N4 suspension on Li foil and then vacuum drying at 100 °C for 1 h. The thickness of the g-C3N4 coating is changed by the amount of suspension that is dropped.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparation of SPAN and the assembly of all-solid-state batteries
ce:section.ce:para: The elemental sulfur powder and polyacrylonitrile were mixed in a ratio of 8:1, and then the sulfide polyacrylonitrile with a sulfur content of 40 % was obtained by heat treatment at 300 °C for 8 h in an argon atmosphere. Li6PS5Cl powder was purchased from MTI for testing. For Li-Li symmetrical cells, 100 mg LPSC powders were firstly cold pressed in a PEEK mold with a diameter of 10 mm at 380 MPa for 5 min, then bare Li foils or Li-GCN foils were place on the both sides of LPSC pellet. For Li-SPAN cells, SPAN, CNTs and Li6PS5Cl are thoroughly ground and mixed in a mortar in a ratio of 20:3:30. Then the sulfur cathode composites were uniformly spread on the one side of the LPSC pellet and pressed at 380 MPa for another 5 min. Finally, a piece of Li foil or Li-GCN foil was attached on the other side of LPSC pellet. All procedures were carried out in a glove box.

X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses were performed by a D8 Advance (Bruker, Germany) with Cu –Kα radiation at a scan rate of 6°/min. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FIRT) was carried out on Spectrum 100 (PerkinElmer, USA). X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS) was carried out by AXIS UltraDLD (Shimadzu-Kratos Corporation, Japan). The Li6PS5Cl was disassembled from the cycled Li-Li symmetrical cells and was placed in a sealed chamber equipped with XPS to avoid exposure to air during transfer. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were conducted by Nova NanoSEM 450 (FEI, USA) and JEM-2100 (JEOL, Japan) respectively. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) was performed on an environment controlled Nanoavi E-sweep (Hitachi, Japan). Electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy (EPR) was carried out by EMXplus-9.5/12 (Bruker, Germany). The time-of-flight secondary-ions mass spectroscopy (TOF-SIMS) three dimensional images and depth profiles were performed using a TOF SIM 500 (ION-TOF GmbH, Germany) which equipped with a high-efficiency electro neutralization gun, the analytical source is equipped with a Bi source (30 keV) and sputtering source is equipped with Cs source of 2 kV. Element analysis (EA) was carried out using a Vario EL III (Elementar, Germany).

All-solid-state cells were assembled with homemade PEEK molds in an argon-filled glovebox (O2 and H2O < 0.1 ppm). Galvanostatic charging and discharging measurements were carried out by Neware battery test system (Shenzhen, China). All-solid-state Li-SPAN cells were tested from 1 V to 3 V under a pressure of 100 MPa. EIS measurements were recorded on the autolab electrochemical workstation (Metrohm, Switzerland) with the AC amplitude of 10 mV at frequencies from 0.1 Hz to 1 MHz. According to the GITT curve, The Li+ diffusion rate (DLi+) of SPAN was calculated by following equation:

Two characteristic peaks of X-ray diffraction appear at 27.2° and 13.1°, corresponding to the (002) and (100) planes (Fig. 2 f). The sharp (002) peak corresponds to the layer spacing of the crystal plane of 0.327 nm, which is the distance of the two-dimensional lattice layer. The broad (100) peak corresponds to a distance of 0.67 nm from layer to layer periodically. These two peaks correspond to the stacking structure of two-dimensional tri-s-triazine ring polymer in GCN [34]. After fully grinding and mixing the bare Li and GCN powder ((Li/GCN) at 100 °C, no obvious new phase appeared in the Li/GCN mixture, indicating that GCN has good thermal and chemical stability [35]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was further employed to explore the detailed chemical state changes of N, C and Li on the surface of Li-GCN. It can be seen from N 1s spectra (Fig. 2 g), the three g-C3N4 characteristic peaks appear at the positions with bonding energy of 398.6 eV, 399.5 eV and 400.8 eV, corresponding to sp2 hybrid aromatic nitrogen atoms (C = N-C) in tri-s-triazine rings, N-(C)3 and N-H groups, respectively [12,36]. The first two nitrogen species constitute the main skeleton structure of g-C3N4, which shows that the basic structure of g-C3N4 is well maintained. It is noteworthy that an additional peak appeared at 398.8 eV for Li-GCN, which was ascribed to the Li-N bond in the generated Li3N[35,37]. Typically, Li metal usually reacts with GCN in a high-temperature molten state (>300 °C). The emergence of Li3N on Li-GCN comes from the partial reaction of Li foil with thin g-C3N4 [36]. As a lithium superionic conductor, Li3N (6 × 10-3 S cm−1) allows rapid Li+ transportation and homogeneous Li+ distribution at the interface[38]. In addition, the structure of GCN is not complete as boron nitride (BN), the molecular structure of tri-s-triazine ring as well as abundant surface defects may provide Li+ transports channels. The change of surface phase of Li-GCN also can be seen from C 1s spectrum. As is shown in Fig. 2 h, the strong peak of g-C3N4 appears at 288.1 eV, indicating that the dominant phase is sp2-hybridized C (N-C = N) in the tri-s-triazine. In addition, two other characteristic peaks of GCN located at 286.5 eV and 284.8 eV, which are derived from N-(C)3 and sp2 C-C bonds [38]. Interestingly, the dominant phase of Li-GCN changed after reacting with Li metal, and sp2 C-C bonds occupied the dominant phase of interface layer, while the N-C = N almost disappeared. Moreover, the existence of Li3N was confirmed in the high-resolution of Li 1s spectrum of Li-GCN (Fig. 2 i). Different from the Li2O dominated interface components of Li metal which was treated by THF solvent, a strong peak at 55.2 eV belonging to the Li3N appeared in Li-GCN [35,37]. The GCN provides an insulating interfacial layer, as shown by direct current conductivity measurement of bare Li and Li-GCN using block electrodes ( Fig. S4 ). The voltage responses of bare Li and Li-GCN are 7.7 mV and 150 mV to an applied current of 5 mA, respectively, which indicates that a high electronic insulation prevents the direct reduction of Li+ on Li-GCN/sulfide electrolyte interface and effectively alleviates the interfacial reaction and decomposition of the sulfide electrolyte.

The Li-argyrodite-Li6PS5Cl was employed owing to its higher ionic conductivity and soft particle properties, a compact LPSC pellet with small grain boundary impedance can be obtained by facile cold pressing [21]. The LPSC particle with rough surface is about 3–5 μm in size ( Fig. S5 ). The XRD pattern shows that the LPSC has typical cubic argyrodite structure with tightly packed anionic tetrahedrons (Fig. S6 a). The ionic conductivity of LPSC pellet measured by blocking electrode is 2.01 × 10-3 S cm−1 at room temperature and the activation energy is calculated by the Arrhenius equation to be 0.283 eV, which is consistent with the data reported in the published literatures [39] (Fig. S6 b).

In order to clearly understand whether the g-C3N4 layer on the Li/sulfide electrolyte interface plays a key role in homogenizing Li stripping and plating, we assembled all-solid-state Li-Li symmetric cells and evaluated their cycling stability and interface compatibility under different test conditions. Fig. S7 compares the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of the symmetric cells with bare Li and Li-GCN electrode. The Li-GCN based cell with a thicker g-C3N4 layer shows a layer interfacial resistance, which could be attributed to the restricted Li+ and electrons pathway in stacked GCN. The N 1s in-depth XPS of Li-GCN was investigated in Fig. S8 . With the increase of Ar-ion sputtering depth, the signals of N became gradually weakened and the optimal thickness of the GCN layer is ∼25 nm without hindering the Li+ diffusion. As shown in Fig. 3
a, both symmetric cells based on bare Li and Li-GCN electrode reveal similar initial overpotentials of 23 mV at a current density of 0.2 mA cm−2. The symmetric Li-GCN cell exhibited Li steady stripping/plating of more than 1100 h just with acceptable overpotential fluctuations caused by ambient temperature fluctuation. In contrast, the bare Li based symmetric cells suffer from an increasing voltage hysteresis and followed by sudden drop at 156 h due to short circuits. The symmetric Li-GCN cell with a thicker GCN layer also ran steadily 800 h ( Fig. S9 ). The similar results have been observed under both high current density and high capacity. The Li-GCN symmetric cells show a constant overpotential over 1600 h cycles with a capacity of 0.5 mAh cm2 (Fig. 3 b). Even at a higher current density of 0.5 mA cm−2, the Li-GCN symmetric cell maintains excellent interfacial stability for 500 h without significant overpotential fluctuations (Fig. 3 c). By contrast, the overpotential of bare Li symmetric cell present a rapid increase during cycling, and finally short-circuit failure occurs in a short time. In addition, the Li-GCN anode-based symmetric cell exhibits increased critical current density of 0.6 mA cm−2 ( Fig. S10 ). Table S1 compares the electrochemical stability of some reported modified SEI in symmetric cells, from which the excellent stability of the GCN modified layer can be seen. According to Sand’s time model [40], when the Li ions concentration at the Li metal surface is zero, the local current density will be maximized, which favors the rapid nucleation of initial metal species and subsequent dendrites growth. The g-C3N4 plays the role of uniformly dispersing Li ions at the electrolyte/electrode interface, avoiding the local increase of current density due to the lack of Li ions, thereby inducing dendrite growth.

To further evaluate the compatibility of Li-GCN with the LPSC electrolyte, we measured the EIS of Li-Li symmetric cells at different cycles, and established a scientific model to reflect the evolution of the interphase. As the equivalent circuit embedded in Fig. 3 (d and e), where the sum of RSSE-b and RSEE-gb corresponds to the material resistance of LPSC electrolyte in the high frequency, Rint represents the Li/LPSC or Li-GCN/LPSC interface resistance. For the bare Li electrode, compared with the 5 cycles, the Rint increased from 16.91 Ω to 27.63 Ω after 50 cycles. The contact between the LPSC and bare Li undergoes a continuous interfacial side reaction due to the narrow electrochemical of sulfide, and the thickening interphase with poor ionic conductivity results in an increase interface resistance and physical deterioration of sulfide electrolyte, which leads to cracks at the interface that induce dendrite growth, thereby giving rise to the continuous degradation or even failure of the battery performance. In contrast to bare Li, the Rint of Li-GCN/LPSC/ Li-GCN cell slightly increased from 18.88 Ω to 23.59 Ω. It shows that the GCN interlayer significantly alleviate interface side reaction and improve the stability the interface between the Li and LPSC by reducing the interface resistance of 6 Ω. The g-C3N4 plays a crucial role in regulating the distribution of Li ions in the interphase, which promoting the deposition and dissolution of metallic Li and avoiding the formation and penetration of Li dendrites.

Furthermore, we intuitively explore the reasons for the huge gap in electrochemical behavior of the Li symmetrical cells between the two by observing the Li surface and cross-sectional morphology of symmetric truncated interface after 150 h. As shown in Fig. 4 (a-d), the Li-GCN has a uniform and smooth surface topography and a close contact electrode/electrolyte interface without obvious cracks. On the contrary, it was evident that some protrusions appeared at the Li surface. The uneven Li deposits grow along the defects and voids on the surface of the solid electrolyte. With the penetration of Li, cracks appear in the interior of the SSE under the coupling of force and electrochemical field ( Fig. S11 ). The mechanical failure raised from Li inhomogeneous stripping/plating prompts Li dendrite to grow along the cracks and triggers short circuit only after few cycles. An inhomogeneous and mechanically brittle SEI is generated when Li comes into direct contact with sulfide electrolyte, which induces the formation of hot spots, a region where the rate of Li deposition/dissolution increases at the Li/electrolyte interface [41]. The hot spots serve as the origin of the dendrite growth and the penetration of solid electrolyte. The stable and flexible GCN interlayer provides abundant N species and Li3N, which homogenizes the Li+ distribution and promotes the orderly Li deposition, thereby effectively suppressing the generation of hot spots and dendrites growth.

It is known from various reported literatures that direct contact of sulfide electrolyte with Li metal will inevitably lead to reduction reaction, resulting in electrolyte decomposition and increase of interfacial resistance [15,42]. In order to confirm the shielding of GCN to the interfacial reaction between Li and LPSC, we analyzed the component evolution of LPSC surface in Li/LPSC/Li and Li-GCN/LPSC/LI-GCN cell after cycling by X-ray photoemission technique (XPS). The Li symmetric cell cycled at 0.2 mA cm−2 for 200 h was disassembled in the glove box, and the solid electrolyte inside was taken out for testing. For the P 2p spectra (Fig. 4 e), both samples exhibited characteristic signatures of PS4 3- tetrahedra at a binding energy of 131.7 eV [43]. The difference is that the LPSC in contact directly with bare Li presents a weak signal at 130.9 eV, which can be assigned to reduced P species. As for S 2p spectra (Fig. 4 f), the peak at 161.3 eV originates from P-S-Li group. Besides, a stronger characteristic peak belonging to Li2S located at 160 eV in the sample without GCN layer separation [44], which indicates more serious interfacial reaction between LPSC and bare Li. Furthermore, the evolution of the surface species of the Li-GCN anode after cycling was analyzed by time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (TOF-SIMS) (Figs. 4 g and S12). It can be seen from three-dimensional cross-sectional views and corresponding depth profiles of various secondary ion species that the distribution of LPSC decomposition products at different depths on the Li-GCN surface. The interphase showed a stratified distribution, that is, LiCl, Li3P, Li2S are mainly distributed in the outermost layer, middle layer, and innermost layer, respectively. The CN– signal is high during the initial sputtering phase, indicating that GCN layer exist on the surface of Li-GCN anode. The signal intensity of Li3P is lower than that of Li2S, indicating that the Li2S plays a dominant role in interphase. The poor ionic conductivity of Li2S is the root cause of the increase in interface resistance. The Li3P and Li2S signals under g-C3N4 layer are weaker compared to the areas without g-C3N4 protection. The above results prove that the presence of chemically inert GCN layer could effectively alleviate the occurrence of Li/LPSC interfacial side reaction. However, the incomplete coating of GCN leads to the side reactions at the interface that cannot be completely eliminated.

Due to the excellent electrochemical performance, SPAN cathode is widely used in the research of electrolyte or lithium anode in practical battery systems [45,46]. We assembled ASSLBs with SPAN cathode (40% of sulfur content) to further verify the feasibility of Li-GCN in practical applications ( Fig. S13 ). As is shown in Fig. 5
a, the Li/LPSC/SPAN cells reveal an ultrahigh initial discharge specific capacity of 780 mAh g−1 at 0.1C, which even exceeds the theoretical specific capacity of SPAN with a sulfur content of 40 % (670 mAh g−1). This irreversible excess discharge capacity is usually attributed to the anionic conjugated backbone of the conductive polymer [47]. However, there is a rapid capacity decay to 210 mAh g−1 in subsequent 100 cycles. With the protection of g-C3N4 layer, although the Li-GCN/LPSC/SPAN cells have a similar initial capacity, a significantly improved capacity retention of 412 mAh g−1 can be observed after 110 cycles. It can be seen from the rate performance test in Fig. 5 b that the specific capacity of Li-GCN/LPSC/SPAN cell is significantly improved compared to Li/LPSC/SPAN cell with the current increases, which indicates the interfacial reaction between Li and LPSC is more serious at large current density. The reason is mainly because the inevitable side reaction at the interface between the sulfide electrolyte and Li metal and the resulting low-ionic conductive Li2S interphase severely hinders the Li+ transport. Fig. 5 c shows the charge/discharge profiles of Li-GCN/LPSC/SPAN cell with different cycles. Similar to liquid electrolyte systems, the initial discharge curve shows excess capacity as well as a lower voltage plateau. The voltage platforms of 2.11 V and 1.52 V appearing on the initial charge and discharge profiles, respectively, indicate the one-step solid–solid conversion reaction. Fig. 5 d shows the charge–discharge profiles of Li-GCN/LPSC/SPAN cell at various C rates, the three-phase interface of the solid–solid contact on the composite SPAN cathode provides limited mass and charge transfer, which greatly reduces the utilization rate of the active materials and the capacity deallocation at high current. The reaction mechanism of SPAN cathode in different charge and discharge states was analyzed by ex-situ electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) (Fig. 5 e). The S-S bond breaks at the first cycle to produce sulfur radicals. As the discharge progresses, the free radical signal gradually increases until the end of the discharge, while the charging process is reversed. Delocalization of electrons on aromatic groups induces the formation of conjugated structures. This conjugated structure stabilizes the free radical and the sulfur radical can be stably stored. In addition, the morphology and structural differences of the composite SPAN before and after cycling were compared ( Fig. S14 ). The composite SPAN maintains a dense structure after cycling, and no obvious cracks appear on the surface and inside. The unique structure of SPAN alleviates the drastic volume changes caused by (de)lithiation, ensuring a good electrons and ions network inside the cathode.

By analyzing the impedance results before and after cycling of all-solid-state Li-SPAN batteries, we can explain why the electrochemical performance of Li-GCN anode has improved. Typically, the EIS of all-solid-state cells consist of three semicircles, located at high frequency (>1MHz), intermediate frequency (1 kHz − 1 MHz) and low frequency (0.1 Hz − 100 Hz) [16,48]. According to the fitted equivalent circuit, the three semicircles from high frequency to low frequency correspond to the bulk resistance of LPSC (Rb), the sum of cathode/SSE interface resistance and anode/SSE interface resistance (Rint) and the charge transfer resistance of cathode (Rct), as well as the Warbury-type resistance (W), which represented diffusion behavior. The resistance fitting results of each part of Li/LPSC/SPAN cell are shown in Fig. 5 f and g, Rb of increased from 41 Ω to 213 Ω after 100 cycles. In the meantime, the Rint and Rct also increased violently from 5 Ω, 8 Ω to 162 Ω and 160 Ω, respectively. With the introduction of g-C3N4 interphase, Li-GCN/LPSC/SPAN cell shows a lower Rb of 187 Ω after 100 cycles, which indicates that the decomposition of LPSC is somewhat suppressed. Rint and Rct increased from 6 Ω,10 Ω to 68 Ω and 68 Ω, respectively (Fig. 5 h and i). It is worth noting that Zhu et al. found through cryo-projection electron microscopy and ab initio molecular dynamics simulations that the interface layer formed by metallic lithium and sulfide electrolytes at high temperatures is polycrystalline Li2S, and the numerous grain boundaries/dislocations occurring inside the layer and the increased thickness leads to ultrahigh interfacial resistance [49]. In addition, the inevitable volume change of SPAN during the cycles leads to the loss of electrons and ions contact, which also causes the increase of the interface resistance and the continuous capacity fading. Anyhow, the g-C3N4 has play a significant role in alleviating Li/LPSC interfacial side reactions and improving the cycling stability of Li-GCN/LPSC/SPAN cell.

There is no doubt that the cycle stability of Li-GCN/LPSC/SPAN cell has been greatly improved with the help of GCN layer, however, its average coulombic efficiency is only ≈99.1% and the reversible specific capacity has continued to decay with the cell cycle. We explored the kinetics of Li ions transport in SPAN cathode during the charging and discharging process of all-solid-state Li-SPAN cell by constant current intermittent titration (GITT) and cyclic voltammetry (CV) [50,51] (Fig. 6
a-d). It can be seen from that the discharge dynamics of SPAN are superior to the charging kinetics and the Li+ diffusion coefficient decreases significantly especially in the later stage of charging. We concluded that the rapid capacity decay of all-solid-state Li-SPAN cells may be due to the poor kinetics in the SPAN cathode during charging. Therefore, the galvanostatic constant-current-constant-voltage (CCCV) charge–discharge method is used to make up the capacity loss in the galvanostatic current charging process. The Li-GCN/LPSC/SPAN cell delivers a reversible capacity of 579 mAh g−1 and a capacity retention of 88 % at 0.2C after 150 cycles (Fig. 6 e). Moreover, the cell shows excellent rate performance and the capacity retentions of Li-GCN/LPSC/SPAN cell are 95%, 91%, 90%, 88%, 84.6% and 82% at 0.1C, 0.2C, 0.3C, 0.5C, 1C and 2C, respectively (Fig. 6 f). The constant voltage charging process effectively supplements the capacity loss caused by the insufficient charging kinetics of solid SPAN cathode. Even at a high SPAN mass loading of 3.84 mg cm−2, the Li-GCN/LPSC/SPAN cell releases an initial discharge capacity of 760 mAh g−1 and maintains a stable operation for 40 cycles ( Fig. S15 ). The above results proved that the stable Li-GCN/LPSC interface allows all-solid-state Li-SPAN to operate at higher currents or higher capacities without short circuit.

In summary, we modified the Li metal anode for all-solid-state Li-S batteries through a facile and inexpensive strategy, which significantly improved the Li/LPSC interface stability. Electronic insulation and electrochemically inert GCN provide a stable interphase between Li anode and LPSC and effectively alleviate the interfacial reaction which is inevitable when Li anode is in direct contact with sulfides. The abundant nitrogen species availably regulate the Li+ distribution at the interphase and uniformize the Li plating and stripping, thereby significantly suppressing the dendrite formation. The electrochemical performance of Li-GCN anode is signified improved compared with bare Li anode, whether in symmetrical cells or in all-solid-state Li-SPAN cells. The strategy to employ a suitable and stable interfacial modification layer to stabilize Li/sulfide SSEs interface is worth further exploring. However, compared with liquid electrolytes, the capacity decay problem of all-solid-state Li-SPAN cell is more prominent, and we will do further research on the SPAN cathode in the future work.

Yao Zhao: Writing – original draft. Huichao Lu: Writing – review & editing. Xirui Kong: Writing – review & editing. Jun Yang: Writing – review & editing. Yanna Nuli: Writing – review & editing. Jiulin Wang: Writing – review & editing, Supervision, Resources.
